mn110:0.2.eng: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

mn110:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
mn110:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

mn110:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā tadahuposathe pannarase puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto abbhokāse nisinno hoti.
mn110:2.1.eng: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.

mn110:2.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn110:2.2.eng: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent. He addressed them,

mn110:3.1.eng: “Mendicants, could an untrue person know of an untrue person:
mn110:3.1.comm: Vassakāra asks the Buddha the same questions at AN 4.187:2.1, with an interesting example given from the court gossip.

mn110:3.2.eng: ‘This worthy one is an untrue person’?”

mn110:3.5.pli: aṭṭhānametaṃ, bhikkhave, anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya:
mn110:3.5.eng: It’s impossible, it can’t happen, that an untrue person could know of an untrue person:

mn110:3.6.eng: ‘This worthy one is an untrue person.’

mn110:3.7.eng: But could an untrue person know of a true person:

mn110:3.8.eng: ‘This worthy one is a true person’?”

mn110:3.11.pli: etampi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhānaṃ anavakāso yaṃ asappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya:

mn110:4.1.pli: Asappuriso, bhikkhave, assaddhammasamannāgato hoti, asappurisabhatti hoti, asappurisacintī hoti, asappurisamantī hoti, asappurisavāco hoti, asappurisakammanto hoti, asappurisadiṭṭhi hoti; asappurisadānaṃ deti.
mn110:4.1.eng: A untrue person has bad qualities, is devoted to untrue persons, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of an untrue person.
mn110:4.1.comm: Bhatti is given in the Abhidhamma Vibhaṅga as a synonym of sevanā, “association” (Vb 17:93.2). While this is correct, the early Pali contexts are more warmly emotional than the rather austere “association”, connecting it with words such as “faith” (saddhā) and “fondness” (pema) (Thag 5.12:1.3, Thig 15.1:14.1, AN 5.141:5.2). This anticipates the later use of bhakti as “(ecstatic religious) devotion”. | “Devotion to untrue persons” is said to be a quality of the Jains (AN 10.78:1.7).

mn110:5.1.eng: And how does an untrue person have bad qualities?

mn110:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappuriso assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, appassuto hoti, kusīto hoti, muṭṭhassati hoti, duppañño hoti.
mn110:5.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person is faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.

mn110:5.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso assaddhammasamannāgato hoti.
mn110:5.3.eng: That’s how an untrue person has bad qualities.

mn110:6.1.eng: And how is an untrue person devoted to untrue persons?

mn110:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappurisassa ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā assaddhā ahirikā anottappino appassutā kusītā muṭṭhassatino duppaññā tyāssa mittā honti te sahāyā.
mn110:6.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person is a friend and companion of ascetics and brahmins who are faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.
mn110:6.2.comm: Where assaddhamma appears in AN 10.62:3.1, it means listening to “untrue teachings”, whereas here it means “bad qualities”.

mn110:6.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso asappurisabhatti hoti.
mn110:6.3.eng: That’s how an untrue person is devoted to untrue persons.

mn110:7.1.eng: And how does an untrue person have the intentions of an untrue person?

mn110:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappuriso attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti.
mn110:7.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both.

mn110:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso asappurisacintī hoti.
mn110:7.3.eng: That’s how an untrue person has the intentions of an untrue person.

mn110:8.1.eng: And how does an untrue person offer the counsel of an untrue person?

mn110:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappuriso attabyābādhāyapi manteti, parabyābādhāyapi manteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi manteti.
mn110:8.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person offers counsel that hurts themselves, hurts others, and hurts both.

mn110:8.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso asappurisamantī hoti.
mn110:8.3.eng: That’s how an untrue person offers the counsel of an untrue person.

mn110:9.1.eng: And how does an untrue person have the speech of an untrue person?

mn110:9.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappuriso musāvādī hoti, pisuṇavāco hoti, pharusavāco hoti, samphappalāpī hoti.
mn110:9.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical.

mn110:9.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso asappurisavāco hoti.
mn110:9.3.eng: That’s how an untrue person has the speech of an untrue person.

mn110:10.1.eng: And how does an untrue person have the action of an untrue person?

mn110:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappuriso pāṇātipātī hoti, adinnādāyī hoti, kāmesumicchācārī hoti.
mn110:10.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct.

mn110:10.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso asappurisakammanto hoti.
mn110:10.3.eng: That’s how an untrue person has the actions of an untrue person.

mn110:11.1.eng: And how does an untrue person have the view of an untrue person?

mn110:11.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person has such a view:

mn110:11.3.pli: ‘natthi dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā, ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
mn110:11.3.eng: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

mn110:11.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso asappurisadiṭṭhi hoti.
mn110:11.4.eng: That’s how an untrue person has the view of an untrue person.

mn110:12.1.eng: And how does an untrue person give the gifts of an untrue person?
mn110:12.1.comm: Also at AN 5.147; see too AN 9.20.

mn110:12.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, asappuriso asakkaccaṃ dānaṃ deti, asahatthā dānaṃ deti, acittīkatvā dānaṃ deti, apaviṭṭhaṃ dānaṃ deti anāgamanadiṭṭhiko dānaṃ deti.
mn110:12.2.eng: It’s when an untrue person gives a gift carelessly, not with their own hand, and thoughtlessly. They give the dregs, and they give without consideration for consequences.

mn110:12.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappuriso asappurisadānaṃ deti.
mn110:12.3.eng: That’s how an untrue person gives the gifts of an untrue person.

mn110:13.1.pli: So, bhikkhave, asappuriso evaṃ assaddhammasamannāgato, evaṃ asappurisabhatti, evaṃ asappurisacintī, evaṃ asappurisamantī, evaṃ asappurisavāco, evaṃ asappurisakammanto, evaṃ asappurisadiṭṭhi;
mn110:13.1.eng: That untrue person—who has such bad qualities, frequents untrue persons, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of an untrue person—

mn110:13.2.pli: evaṃ asappurisadānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā yā asappurisānaṃ gati tattha upapajjati.
mn110:13.2.eng: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the place where untrue persons are reborn.

mn110:13.3.eng: And what is the place where untrue persons are reborn?

mn110:13.4.comm: At AN 2.26–29 these destinies are said to await one who hides misdeeds, who has wrong view, and who is unethical. At MN 97:30.3 it is said that, of the two, the animal realm is better.

mn110:14.1.pli: Jāneyya nu kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisaṃ:
mn110:14.1.eng: Mendicants, could a true person know of a true person:

mn110:14.2.eng: ‘This worthy one is a true person’?”

mn110:14.5.pli: ṭhānametaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ sappuriso sappurisaṃ jāneyya:
mn110:14.5.eng: It is possible that a true person could know of a true person:

mn110:14.6.eng: ‘This worthy one is a true person.’

mn110:14.7.eng: But could a true person know of an untrue person:

mn110:14.8.eng: ‘This worthy one is an untrue person’?”

mn110:15.2.pli: etampi kho, bhikkhave, ṭhānaṃ vijjati yaṃ sappuriso asappurisaṃ jāneyya:

mn110:15.4.pli: Sappuriso, bhikkhave, saddhammasamannāgato hoti, sappurisabhatti hoti, sappurisacintī hoti, sappurisamantī hoti, sappurisavāco hoti, sappurisakammanto hoti, sappurisadiṭṭhi hoti;
mn110:15.4.eng: A true person has good qualities, is devoted to true persons, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of a true person.

mn110:16.1.eng: And how does a true person have good qualities?

mn110:16.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappuriso saddho hoti, hirimā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, upaṭṭhitassati hoti, paññavā hoti.
mn110:16.2.eng: It’s when a true person is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

mn110:16.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso saddhammasamannāgato hoti.
mn110:16.3.eng: That’s how a true person has good qualities.

mn110:17.1.eng: And how is a true person devoted to true persons?

mn110:17.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappurisassa ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhā hirimanto ottappino bahussutā āraddhavīriyā upaṭṭhitassatino paññavanto tyāssa mittā honti, te sahāyā.
mn110:17.2.eng: It’s when a true person is a friend and companion of ascetics and brahmins who are faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

mn110:17.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisabhatti hoti.
mn110:17.3.eng: That’s how a true person is devoted to true persons.

mn110:18.1.eng: And how does a true person have the intentions of a true person?

mn110:18.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappuriso nevattabyābādhāya ceteti, na parabyābādhāya ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāya ceteti.
mn110:18.2.eng: It’s when a true person doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both.

mn110:18.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisacintī hoti.
mn110:18.3.eng: That’s how a true person has the intentions of a true person.

mn110:19.1.eng: And how does a true person offer the counsel of a true person?

mn110:19.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappuriso nevattabyābādhāya manteti, na parabyābādhāya manteti, na ubhayabyābādhāya manteti.
mn110:19.2.eng: It’s when a true person offers counsel that doesn’t hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both.

mn110:19.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisamantī hoti.
mn110:19.3.eng: That’s how a true person offers the counsel of a true person.

mn110:20.1.eng: And how does a true person have the speech of a true person?

mn110:20.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappuriso musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti.
mn110:20.2.eng: It’s when a true person refrains from speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical.

mn110:20.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisavāco hoti.
mn110:20.3.eng: That’s how a true person has the speech of a true person.

mn110:21.1.eng: And how does a true person have the action of a true person?

mn110:21.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappuriso pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti.
mn110:21.2.eng: It’s when a true person refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct.

mn110:21.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisakammanto hoti.
mn110:21.3.eng: That’s how a true person has the action of a true person.

mn110:22.1.eng: And how does a true person have the view of a true person?

mn110:22.2.eng: It’s when a true person has such a view:

mn110:22.3.pli: ‘atthi dinnaṃ, atthi yiṭṭhaṃ, atthi hutaṃ, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, atthi ayaṃ loko, atthi paro loko, atthi mātā, atthi pitā, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedentī’ti.
mn110:22.3.eng: ‘There is meaning in giving, sacrifice, and offerings. There are fruits and results of good and bad deeds. There is an afterlife. There are such things as mother and father, and beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there are ascetics and brahmins who are rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describe the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’

mn110:22.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisadiṭṭhi hoti.
mn110:22.4.eng: That’s how a true person has the view of a true person.

mn110:23.1.eng: And how does a true person give the gifts of a true person?

mn110:23.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sappuriso sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ deti, sahatthā dānaṃ deti, cittīkatvā dānaṃ deti, anapaviṭṭhaṃ dānaṃ deti, āgamanadiṭṭhiko dānaṃ deti.
mn110:23.2.eng: It’s when a true person gives a gift carefully, with their own hand, and thoughtfully. They don’t give the dregs, and they give with consideration for consequences.

mn110:23.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso sappurisadānaṃ deti.
mn110:23.3.eng: That’s how a true person gives the gifts of a true person.

mn110:24.1.pli: So, bhikkhave, sappuriso evaṃ saddhammasamannāgato, evaṃ sappurisabhatti, evaṃ sappurisacintī, evaṃ sappurisamantī, evaṃ sappurisavāco, evaṃ sappurisakammanto, evaṃ sappurisadiṭṭhi;
mn110:24.1.eng: That true person—who has such good qualities, is devoted to true persons, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of a true person—

mn110:24.2.pli: evaṃ sappurisadānaṃ datvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā yā sappurisānaṃ gati tattha upapajjati.
mn110:24.2.eng: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the place where true persons are reborn.

mn110:24.3.eng: And what is the place where true persons are reborn?

mn110:24.4.eng: A state of greatness among gods or humans.”

mn110:25.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn110:25.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn110:25.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
